ZfCA2DT0.title: Research on Growth Limit of Urban Space Based on the Stability of Ecosystem:A Case Study of Beijing
ZfCA2DT0.abstract: Being in some state of the ecological environment,the formation and development of the city are supported and restricted by ecological system and environmental capacity.In the background of land space strongly demanded which required by the production activities,people ignores the limitation of resources and vulnerability of environment.In the past 30 years,high speed industrialization and urbanization caused so many problems in China,such as disorderly development of land space,the deterioration of ecology and the environment,the enhancement of resources pressure.Therefore,it is very important for us to make sure the growth limit of urban space and construct the reasonable urban and rural land-use pattern,that we can easily understand the binding mechanism in the process of the urban expansion and carry out the city planning and land use planning work.The target of this article is to pursue relative optimization of regional living environment.From the perspective of city,through analyzing the land ecologic suitability evaluation,we have studied whether the ecological landscape unit is suitable for the development and utilization of human activities or not.Specifically,taking the city of Beijing for example,from the four aspects of the type of land use/land cover,terrain slope,ecological function and ecological value,we established the landscape process resistance evaluation system.Using the minimal cumulative resistance model and the spatial analysis tool of ArcGIS,we have got the distribution of minimal cumulative resistance of urban space growth in Beijing;At the same time,using the rules of the World City space structure,we try to determine the urban space growth limit and threshold value interval of Beijing,at a certain stage of economic development and level of production technology inputs.

vcZ7QA1D.title: A Literature Review of Research on Territorial Function Identifying
vcZ7QA1D.abstract: This paper provides a review and reflection on the research about the territorial function identifying,in terms of the research foundation,indicator system and research methods.The results reveal that:1)The research about the mechanism of territorial function evolution is comparatively inadequate,there isn′t a unified classification of the territorial function and the indicator system;2)There is a paradigm to the research:to identify the function′from easy to difficult′,according to suitability assessment and function discrimination,with the assistant of space analysis,but some technical problem should be solved in the comprehensive integration;3)The research scale is shift to the county or city level,despite the type of identifying should be discussed.The paper puts forward several prospects on researches of territorial function identifying:to reinforce the research of evolution mechanism,to develop the standardization of classification system,indicator system and the research method,to establish the mechanism of monitoring,the post-assessment and the dynamic adjustment.

wcT7nrS0.title: Study of solid solubility of gold doped in ZnO films and its effect on optical properties
wcT7nrS0.abstract: Gold-doped ZnO (ZnO:Au) thin films with different Au content were fabricated by radio frequency magnetron sputtering and post annealing techniques. The solid solubility of Au in ZnO was found smaller or equal to 1.00 at.% for the ZnO:Au annealed at 350 C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results suggest that Au exists in ZnO:Au with chemical state of AuZnu0027+ while the Au content is 1.00 at.%, once the Au content is larger than 1.00 at.%, Au exists in the ZnO with chemical state of metallic Au in the grain boundary and AuZn1+ in the ZnO:Au. While the incorporation of Au in the ZnO films seem to quench both the band edge and visible emissions of the ZnO films, and the degree of photoluminescence quenching increases with the increasing Au content. PL quenching of the ZnO:Au is attributed to the substitutional doping of Au in the ZnO films, while the degree of quenching may related to the content of metallic Au in the ZnO:Au.

v6hUl5GJ.title: In situ generated thrombin in the protein corona of zeolites: Relevance of the functional proteins to its biological impact
v6hUl5GJ.abstract: Adsorption of plasma proteins to nanomaterial surfaces has a great influence on their bio-functionality. However, there is limited understanding of the relationship between the functional proteins in the protein corona and the biological identity of the materials. Here we show that the in situ generated thrombin in the protein corona of a Ca-zeolite surface displays a calcium-dependent, unusually high (∼3,000 NIH U/mg) procoagulant activity, which is even stable against antithrombin deactivation. Removing the encapsulated Ca2+ in the zeolites leads to deactivation by antithrombin. Our observations suggest that the thrombin activity can be regulated by the inorganic surface and cations. Most importantly, our discovery indicates the link between the biomolecules in the protein corona and the procoagulant activity of the materials, providing a new molecular basis for the procoagulant mechanism for zeolite hemostatics.

wDfEjSyP.title: Hemorrhagic shock activates lung endothelial reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase via neutrophil NADPH oxidase.
wDfEjSyP.abstract: The vascular endothelium plays an important role in the regulation of inflammatory responses after trauma and hemorrhage. Interactions of neutrophils with endothelial cells (ECs) contribute to the activation of specific EC responses involved in innate immunity. We have previously reported that oxidants derived from the neutrophil reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase is a critical regulator to EC activation. Our objective was to test the role of neutrophil NADPH oxidase-derived oxidants in mediating and enhancing hemorrhagic shock (HS)-induced activation of lung endothelial NADPH oxidase. Mice were subjected to HS and neutrophil depletion. The mice were also replenished with the neutrophil from NADPH oxidase-deficient mice. The resultant activation of lung NADPH oxidase was analyzed. The in vivo studies were also recapitulated with in vitro neutrophil-EC coculture system. HS induces NADPH oxidase activation in neutrophils and lung through high-mobility group box 1/Toll-like receptor 4-dependent signaling. In neutropenic mice, shock-induced NADPH oxidase activation in the lung was reduced significantly, but was restored upon repletion with neutrophils obtained from wild-type mice subjected to shock, but not with neutrophils from shock mice lacking the gp91(phox) subunit of NADPH oxidase. The findings were recapitulated in mouse lung vascular ECs cocultured with neutrophils. The data further demonstrate that neutrophil-derived oxidants are key factors mediating augmented High mobility group box 1 (HMGB1)-induced endothelial NADPH oxidase activation through a Rac1-dependent, but p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase-independent, pathway. Oxidant signaling by neutrophil NADPH oxidase is an important determinant of activation of endothelial NADPH oxidase after HS.

jvRBVkJF.title: Gasdermin D protects against noninfectious liver injury by regulating apoptosis and necroptosis.
jvRBVkJF.abstract: Gasdermin D (GsdmD) was recently identified as the executioner of pyroptotic inflammatory cell death, and is a substrate for caspases-1 and 11. GsdmD is detrimental in lethal endotoxemia but protective in bacterial sepsis. However, little is known about its role during noninfectious/sterile injuries. In this study, we examined the contribution of GsdmD using WT and GsdmD mice in two models of noninfectious liver injury: hemorrhagic shock with resuscitation (HS/R) and acetaminophen (APAP) overdose. GsdmD mice had significantly increased liver damage at 6 h after HS/R or APAP vs WT, shown by significantly elevated ALT level and extended areas of cell death in liver. Caspase-8, a mediator of multiple cell death pathways, was highly elevated in GsdmD mice after injury. Significantly increased cleavage of caspase-8 and subsequent high levels of apoptosis were found in livers of GsdmD mice after HS/R, a relatively mild ROS-induced liver injury. However, during more severe APAP-mediated ROS-induced liver injury, caspase-8 cleavage in GsdmD liver was inhibited compared with WT, resulting in accumulation of pro-caspase-8 and increased levels of necroptosis. Our findings indicate a novel hepatoprotective role for GsdmD in noninfectious inflammation models via regulation of caspase-8 expression and downstream cell death pathways. The effects of GsdmD protection are likely injury specific and may also depend on injury severity and levels of ROS produced. These data suggest modulation of GsdmD/caspase-8 may be a novel therapeutic option in ROS-mediated liver injury.

4kbD5nuD.title: Hard-templating synthesis of a novel rod-like nanoporous calcium phosphate bioceramics and their capacity as antibiotic carriers
4kbD5nuD.abstract: Calcium phosphate ceramics analogous to the mineral component of bones, their biocompatibility and osteoconductive properties make them desirable as implant materials and delivery agents of drug and DNA molecules. Here we report a hard-templating synthesis of nanoporous calcium phosphate ceramics, which is based on filling the calcium and phosphorus sources into the nanospaces of rod-like ordered mesoporous carbon (CMK-3). The removal of the carbon template by combustion leads to rod-like nanoporous calcium phosphate bioceramics. They have disordered three-dimensional (3D) interconnected nanopores with diameter of 20–30 nm. The wall thickness is approximately 20–30 nm. Based on nitrogen sorption isotherms, the pore size, surface area and pore volume of this material is ∼30 nm, 27 m 2 g −1 and 0.27 cm 3 g −1 , respectively. Wide-angle XRD and IR measurements reveal that the inorganic walls of products consist of highly crystalline calcium phosphates with main hydroxyapatite phases. In antibiotic charging experiments, these nanoporous bioceramics show a much higher charging capacity (1621 μg g −1 ) than that of commercially available calcium phosphate (100 μg g −1 ), which does not have any nanoporosity. Keywords Hard-templating Nanoporous calcium phosphate ceramics In vitro drug release 1 Introduction In the past decade, significant research efforts have been devoted to achieve materials with well-defined nanostructures for adsorption, catalytic, electronic, and optical applications [1–4] . Calcium phosphate bioceramics (denoted as CPBs) analogous to the mineral component of bones, their biocompatibility and osteoconductive properties make them desirable as implant materials and delivery agents of drug and DNA molecules [5] . Until now, most researches have been focused on the macrostructure process to obtain these biomaterials with various morphologies (films, spheres, etc. ) or macropores for the intergrowth of natural bones [6–12] . However, there are few reports about CPBs with nano- or meso-structures, which may offer some unique properties not exhibited in bulk CPBs [13,14] . For example, the increase in surface area resulted from the nanoporosity might contribute to a carrier's capacity of charging a drug. “Supermolecular-templating” process has been confirmed to be a valuable route to prepare nanoporous/structured inorganic frameworks with diverse composition (including silicas, metals, metal oxides, metal phosphates, and organosilicates) [2,15,16] . However, this process encounters limitations to form CPBs networks, which may be due to the difficulty of efficient control over the crystallization. Here, we report the synthesis of novel nanoporous (20–30 nm) calcium phosphate ceramics (nano-CPBs) with well-defined rod-like morphology based on filling the calcium and the phosphorus source into the nanospaces of rod-like ordered mesoporous carbon (CMK-3) and subsequent removal of carbon templates by combustion (600 °C/air, 5 h) (see Scheme 1 ). As a carrier for charging antibiotics, the storage capacity of these nanoporous biomaterials is 16 times larger than that of non-porous CPBs (non-CPBs) and commercially available CPBs (com-CPBs). 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis Rod-like mesoporous carbon (CMK-3) was prepared by using rod-like mesoporous silica SBA-15 as a template [17] . Rod-like SBA-15 was synthesized by using the block copolymer Pluronic P123 EO 20 PO 70 EO 20 as the template with the addition of inorganic salt, KCl. For the synthesis of rod-like CMK-3, rod-like SBA-15 was impregnated with sucrose in the presence of sulfuric acid, the resulting mixture was dried at 100 °C and subsequently at 160 °C. The obtained sample was carbonized at 900 °C under N 2 atmosphere and finally the silica template was removed by 10 wt.% HF solution to obtain mesoporous carbon. In a typical synthesis of nanoporous calcium phosphates, 0.25 g of the rod-like carbon template (CMK-3) was suspended in 2.0 g of ethanol. To this solution, 3.0 mmol of calcium chloride and 2.0 mmol of OP(OCH 3 ) 3 was added with vigorous stirring in a crucible for 2 h. This suspension was evaporated at 40 °C in air for 2 days. The sample was then aged at 100 °C for 5 h, and calcined at 600 °C in air for 6 h to obtained the final nanoporous products. 2.2 Antibiotic charging experiment In a typical antibiotic charging experiment, norfloxacins were dissolved in a simulated body fluid (SBF) to make a stock solution (30 μg ml −1 ). SBF was prepared by the literature method and buffered to pH 7.4 with tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane and 1.0 M HCl. Kinetic experiments to determine the amount of norfloxacin adsorbed as a function of contact time were conducted by stirring 40 mg of nano-CPBs (1.0 g of non-CPBs and com-CPBs) and 40 ml of stock solution at 37 °C. Samples were withdrawn periodically for immediate analysis and then returned to the mixture. Adsorbed amounts were measured by the difference of the concentration of the antibiotics before and after adsorption using UV adsorption at 274 nm. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D4 ENDEAVOR diffractometer with a scan rate of 1 ° min −1 using Ni-filtered with Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 0.15418 nm). Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 at 77 K. The calcined samples were degassed at 250 °C for 3 h prior to the analysis. Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) images were recorded on JEOL 2011 microscope operated at 200 kV. Sample particles were suspended in ethanol and the suspension was deposited on a copper grid coated with a polymer supported film and carbon. Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) images were recorded on Philips XL30 operated at 20 kV. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded at room temperature using a JASCO V-550 spectrophotometer (Japan) equipped with an integrating sphere. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on an AUATAR 360 FT-IR (Nicolet) analyzer (resolution 4 cm −1 ) at ambient temperature, with the samples pressed into disks with KBr. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 a shows the SEM image of mesoporous carbon obtained after the removal of rod-like mesoporous silica SBA-15 template. The rod-like morphology, with average length of ∼1.0 μm, is still retained after the high temperature treatment (900 °C in N 2 ) and the chemical reaction to remove silica frameworks. Combined with small-angle XRD pattern and TEM analysis (not shown), the final product is proved to be 2D hexagonal mesostructure with the space group of p 6 mm , which is typical for the replica of the mesoporous silica SBA-15 powders [17] . From nitrogen sorption isotherms, the pore volume, pore size and surface area of rod-like mesoporous carbons is 1.2 cm 3 g −1 , 3.0 nm, and 1200 m 2 g −1 , respectively. Nano-CPBs are prepared in two steps: (1) partial nanocasting of the calcium and the phosphorus sources into the nanospaces of rod-like mesoporous carbon CMK-3 by an ethanol evaporation process and (2) subsequent removal of carbon frameworks by combustion. Nanocrystals of CPBs formed and aggregated into disordered nanoporous CPBs networks ( Scheme 1 ). SEM images ( Fig. 1 b) show that the morphologies of the final product nano-CPBs have similar rod-like shapes to those of mesoporous carbons. In contrast to the smooth surface of mesoporous carbon CMK-3 rods, the surface of CPBs rods is very rough ( Fig. 1 b). There is no obvious change of the rod length, although the diameter of the rods decreased from the original ∼300 to ∼200 nm, indicating a rough 55% volume shrinkage. This may be due to the incomplete filling of the calcium phosphates. Based on the specific pore volume (1.2 cm 3 g −1 ) of the mesoporous carbon CMK-3 and the density of CPBs (3.1 g cm −3 , for Ca 3 P 2 O 8 ), the CPBs only fill 33% of the nanospaces of mesoporous carbon CMK-3. Increasing the ratio of inorganic precursors to CMK-3 does not further increase the filling percentage, as it results in the growth of CPBs outside the nanospaces of mesoporous carbon CMK-3. TEM images ( Fig. 1 c, inset) reveal that the nano-CPBs have disordered 3D interconnected nanopores with a diameter of 20–30 nm, which is much larger than the diameter (∼8 nm) of the hexagonally arranged carbon-rods of CMK-3. The wall thickness (20–30 nm) of nano-CPBs is also much larger than the pore size of the mesoporous carbon. To understand the role of the carbon templates in the synthesis of nano-CPBs, the CPBs samples were also prepared by a similar solvent evaporation process, in which carbon templates are absent or replaced by block copolymers. In both cases, TEM and SEM images show that the final calcined products are bulk crystals without showing any nanoporosity ( Supplementary material ). These control experiments suggest that it is easy for CPBs to grow into bulk crystals without efficient control of the crystallization. Whereas, the hard templates (rod-like mesoporous carbon CMK-3) can partially prevent the crystallization of CPBs from growing into bulky crystals and generate nanoporosity during the combustion. The energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) reveals that these rod-like bioceramics are composed of non-stoichiometric calcium phosphate (Ca/P molar ratio is 1.47:1). Selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the sample confirms that the products consist of the nanocrystals of CPBs. Wide-angle XRD analysis ( Fig. 2 a ) shows that the main phase of nano-CPBs is hydroxyapatite, similar to previous report [13] . The structural properties have been further investigated by sorption measurements and infrared spectroscopy (IR). Based on nitrogen sorption isotherms ( Fig. 3 ), its pore size, surface area and pore volume is ∼30 nm, 27 m 2 g −1 and 0.27 cm 3 g −1 , respectively. Fig. 4 shows the FT-IR spectrum of the nano-CPBs templated by mesoporous carbon CMK-3, which is a typical spectrum for calcium phosphates. The strong adsorption at 1056 and 566 cm −1 can be assigned to the ν 3 P–O stretching and ν 4 bending mode of the phosphate, respectively. Owing to their biocompatibility and osteoconductive property, CPBs have recently been considered as a potential alternative material for a drug delivery system, which can store and release a therapeutic agent in situ to produce an action associated with the osteoconductivity of CPBs and the effect of the released therapeutic agent [18] . Generally, these drugs could be adsorbed only onto the surface of CPBs for the implant of bones, their accessible surface and volume of these bulk ceramics inherently limit their loading and release characteristics [19] . The increase in surface area, resulting from nanoporosity, of nano-CPBs, might benefit their capacity as a drug carrier. As a comparison, nano-CPBs, non-porous CPBs, prepared in the absence of mesoporous carbon (non-CPBs) and commercially available CPBs (com-CPBs) (Ca/P = 1.5) were used to store an antibiotic (norfloxacin) in the experiments. According to the XRD results, the phase of non-CPBs is mainly hydroxyapatite similar to nano-CPBs, and com-CPBs have hydroxyapatite and β-tricalcium phosphate mixed phases ( Fig. 2 b). TEM and SEM images show that the non-CPBs consist of irregular large monolith-like particles (10–100 μm) with smooth surfaces after milling and the typical particle size of com-CPBs is ∼1 μm. Both com-CPBs and non-CPBs have a very low surface area <5 m 2 g −1 . The antibiotic charging measurements show that the adsorption of norfloxacin on three CPBs samples is very quick. Every sample reaches the adsorption equilibrium within 10 min. The specific storage capacity of nano-CPBs, non-CPBs, and com-CPBs are 1621, 60, 100 μg g −1 , respectively ( Fig. 5 ). As expected, nano-CPBs prepared by using mesoporous carbon as a hard template shows much higher charging amount of norfloxacin (>16 times) than those of non-CPBs and com-CPBs. The charged CPBs were also re-exposed to the SBF to study their release behaviors. All CPBs charged with norfloxacin show a complete (∼95%) and quick (within 30 min) release of the antibiotics ( Fig. 5 , inset). Previous research on macroporous CPBs has reported similar results [12] . The quick release of antibiotics is undesired, and further functionalization of the surface of nano-CPBs is required to achieve controlled release. In summary, rod-like nanoporous calcium phosphate ceramics have been synthesized using hard-templating method. As drug carriers, these nanoporous bioceramics show much higher charging capacity of antibiotics than that of commercially available bulk bioceramics without nanoporosity. Since the morphologies of mesoporous carbons can be efficiently controlled [20] , the control of macrostructures of these novel nanoporous bioceramics can been achieved. This facilitates their future application in biomedicines. Acknowledgments We thank Mr. Calum Dickson for suggestions.
